text: If today the newspapers as a whole are discussing how many miles separate the Red Army from Warsaw, if politicians and lovers of politics discuss how many months separate us from the defeat of Germany, it is because Russia held out in 1941 and '42.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: [Early] 1943-Folksvillen(Swedish journal):'We published Ilya Ehrenburg's comments on Hitler's latest speech. We omitted certain passages so that there should be nothing insulting to [Hitler]. No objections [...] were raised by [...] press control [authorities]. [N]ext day a cabinet meeting was held [..] the decision was taken [to confiscate all] copies of the issue carrying Ehrenburg's article ...'.

text: Hitler's invasion of the Soviet Union began in the early hours of 22 June 1941. Stalin, refusing to believe that he could be tricked, had rejected more than eighty warnings. Although the Soviet dictator did not collapse until later, he was so disorientated on discovering the truth that the announcement on the wireless at midday was made by his foreign minister, Vyacheslav Molotov, in a wooden voice. The people of the Soviet Union proved rather more robust than their leaders. They queued to volunteer for the front.
sourceAPA: Grossman, V. (2010). A Writer At War: Vasily Grossman with the Red Army 1941-1945. United Kingdom: Random House.
